knowledges.speaker: Joey

synsets.definition: have the quality of being; (copula, used with an adjective or a predicate noun)
_examples: This is not a good answer

synsets.definition: be identical to; be someone or something
_examples: The president of the company is John Smith

synsets.definition: occupy a certain position or area; be somewhere
_examples: Where is my umbrella?" "The toolshed is in the back

synsets.definition: have an existence, be extant
happen, occur, take place; this was during the visit to my parents' house"
_examples: There were two hundred people at his funeral
There was a lot of noise in the kitchen

synsets.definition: be identical or equivalent to
_examples: One dollar equals 1,000 rubles these days!

synsets.definition: form or compose
_examples: This money is my only income
The stone wall was the backdrop for the performance
The children made up the chorus
This sum represents my entire income for a year
These few men comprise his entire army

synsets.definition: work in a specific place, with a specific subject, or in a specific function
represent, as of a character on stage
spend or use time
have life, be alive
_examples: Our great leader is no more
My grandfather lived until the end of war

synsets.definition: to remain unmolested, undisturbed, or uninterrupted -- used only in infinitive form
be priced at

knowledges.origin_sent: Monica, I'm tellin ' you, this guy is perfect for you.

synsets.definition: assign a specified (usually proper) proper name to
_examples: The new school was named after the famous Civil Rights leader

synsets.definition: ascribe a quality to or give a name of a common noun that reflects a quality
_examples: She called her children lazy and ungrateful

synsets.definition: get or try to get into communication (with someone) by telephone
_examples: I tried to call you all night
Take two aspirin and call me in the morning

synsets.definition: utter a sudden loud cry
_examples: she cried with pain when the doctor inserted the needle
I yelled to her from the window but she couldn't hear me

synsets.definition: order, request, or command to come
_examples: She was called into the director's office

synsets.definition: pay a brief visit
_examples: The mayor likes to call on some of the prominent citizens

synsets.definition: call a meeting; invite or command to meet
_examples: The Wannsee Conference was called to discuss the `Final Solution'
The new dean calls meetings every week

synsets.definition: read aloud to check for omissions or absentees
send a message or attempt to reach someone by radio, phone, etc.; make a signal to in order to transmit a message
_examples: A transmitter in Samoa was heard calling

synsets.definition: utter a characteristic note or cry
stop or postpone because of adverse conditions, such as bad weather
greet, as with a prescribed form, title, or name
_examples: She calls him by first name

synsets.definition: make a stop in a harbour
_examples: The ship will call in Honolulu tomorrow

synsets.definition: demand payment of (a loan)
make a demand, as for a card or a suit or a show of hands
give the calls (to the dancers) for a square dance
indicate a decision in regard to
_examples: call balls and strikes behind the plate

synsets.definition: make a prediction about; tell in advance
_examples: Call the outcome of an election

synsets.definition: require the presentation of for redemption before maturation
challenge (somebody) to make good on a statement; charge with or censure for an offense
_examples: He deserves to be called on that

synsets.definition: declare in the capacity of an umpire or referee
lure by imitating the characteristic call of an animal
order or request or give a command for
_examples: The unions called a general strike for Sunday

synsets.definition: order, summon, or request for a specific duty or activity, work, role
_examples: He was already called 4 times for jury duty
They called him to active military duty

synsets.definition: utter in a loud voice or announce
challenge the sincerity or truthfulness of
_examples: call the speaker on a question of fact

synsets.definition: consider or regard as being
_examples: I would not call her beautiful

synsets.definition: rouse somebody from sleep with a call
_examples: I was called at 5 A.M. this morning

knowledges.origin_sent: Me, I go on three auditions a month and call myself an actor, but Bob is ...

knowledges.speaker: Joey

synsets.definition: inquire about
_examples: I asked about their special today
He had to ask directions several times

synsets.definition: make a request or demand for something to somebody
_examples: She asked him for a loan

synsets.definition: direct or put; seek an answer to
consider obligatory; request and expect
_examples: We require our secretary to be on time
Aren't we asking too much of these children?
I expect my students to arrive in time for their lessons

synsets.definition: address a question to and expect an answer from
_examples: The children asked me about their dead grandmother

synsets.definition: require as useful, just, or proper
_examples: It takes nerve to do what she did
This job asks a lot of patience and skill
This position demands a lot of personal sacrifice
This dinner calls for a spectacular dessert
This intervention does not postulate a patient's consent

synsets.definition: require or ask for as a price or condition
_examples: He is asking $200 for the table
The kidnappers are asking a million dollars in return for the release of their hostage

knowledges.origin_sent: Look, I'm asking a favor here.

knowledges.speaker: Joey

synsets.definition: engage in
carry out or perform an action
_examples: John did the painting, the weeding, and he cleaned out the gutters
the skater executed a triple pirouette

synsets.definition: get (something) done
proceed or get along
_examples: How is she doing in her new job?
How are you making out in graduate school?

synsets.definition: give rise to; cause to happen or occur, not always intentionally
carry out or practice; as of jobs and professions
be sufficient; be adequate, either in quality or quantity
_examples: This car suits my purpose well
A 'B' grade doesn't suffice to get me into medical school

synsets.definition: create or design, often in a certain way
_examples: I did this piece in wood to express my love for the forest

synsets.definition: behave in a certain manner; show a certain behavior; conduct or comport oneself
_examples: You should act like an adult
What makes her do this way?
The dog acts ferocious, but he is really afraid of people

synsets.definition: spend time in prison or in a labor camp
_examples: He did six years for embezzlement

synsets.definition: carry on or function
_examples: We could do with a little more help around here

synsets.definition: arrange attractively
_examples: dress my hair for the wedding

synsets.definition: travel or traverse (a distance)
_examples: This car does 150 miles per hour
We did 6 miles on our hike every day

knowledges.origin_sent: If I do this for her brother, maybe Angela will come back to me.

knowledges.speaker: Joey

synsets.definition: engage in
give certain properties to something
_examples: He made a fool of himself at the meeting
Don't make this into a big deal
This invention will make you a millionaire

synsets.definition: make or cause to be or to become
_examples: make a mess in one's office

synsets.definition: cause to do; cause to act in a specified manner
_examples: The ads induced me to buy a VCR
My children finally got me to buy a computer
My wife made me buy a new sofa

synsets.definition: give rise to; cause to happen or occur, not always intentionally
create or manufacture a man-made product
_examples: We produce more cars than we can sell
The company has been making toys for two centuries

synsets.definition: make, formulate, or derive in the mind
_examples: What do you make of his remarks?

synsets.definition: compel or make somebody or something to act in a certain way
_examples: People cannot be made to integrate just by passing a law!

synsets.definition: create by artistic means
earn on some commercial or business transaction; earn as salary or wages
_examples: How much do you make a month in your new job?
She earns a lot in her new job
this merger brought in lots of money

synsets.definition: create or design, often in a certain way
_examples: I did this piece in wood to express my love for the forest

synsets.definition: to compose or represent:"This wall forms the background of the stage setting"
reach a goal, e.g., "make the first team"
_examples: She may not make the grade

synsets.definition: be or be capable of being changed or made into
_examples: He will make a fine father

synsets.definition: make by shaping or bringing together constituents
perform or carry out
make by combining materials and parts
_examples: this little pig made his house out of straw
Some eccentric constructed an electric brassiere warmer

synsets.definition: change from one form into another
act in a certain way so as to acquire
charge with a function; charge to be
_examples: She was named Head of the Committee
She was made president of the club

synsets.definition: achieve a point or goal
reach a destination, either real or abstract
_examples: We barely made it to the finish line
I have to hit the MAC machine before the weekend starts

synsets.definition: institute, enact, or establish
carry out or commit
form by assembling individuals or constituents
organize or be responsible for
_examples: have, throw, or make a party

synsets.definition: put in order or neaten
head into a specified direction
_examples: The escaped convict took to the hills

synsets.definition: have a bowel movement
_examples: The dog had made in the flower beds

synsets.definition: undergo fabrication or creation
_examples: This wool makes into a nice sweater

synsets.definition: be suitable for
add up to
amount to
_examples: This salary increase makes no difference to my standard of living

synsets.definition: constitute the essence of
appear to begin an activity
_examples: He made to speak but said nothing in the end
She made as if to say hello to us

synsets.definition: proceed along a path
_examples: work one's way through the crowd
make one's way into the forest

synsets.definition: reach in time
gather and light the materials for
prepare for eating by applying heat
_examples: can you make me an omelette?
fix breakfast for the guests, please

synsets.definition: induce to have sex
assure the success of
_examples: A good review by this critic will make your play!

synsets.definition: represent fictitiously, as in a play, or pretend to be or act like
consider as being
_examples: It wasn't the problem some people made it

synsets.definition: calculate as being
_examples: I make the height about 100 feet

synsets.definition: cause to be enjoyable or pleasurable
favor the development of
develop into
_examples: He will make a splendid father!

synsets.definition: behave in a certain way
eliminate urine
_examples: Again, the cat had made on the expensive rug

knowledges.origin_sent: I know, but, I made a huge mistake.

synsets.definition: give help or assistance; be of service
_examples: Everyone helped out during the earthquake
Can you help me carry this table?
She never helps around the house

synsets.definition: improve the condition of
_examples: These pills will help the patient

synsets.definition: be of use
_examples: This will help to prevent accidents

synsets.definition: abstain from doing; always used with a negative
_examples: I can't help myself--I have to smoke
She could not help watching the sad spectacle

synsets.definition: help to some food; help with food or drink
_examples: I served him three times, and after that he helped himself

synsets.definition: contribute to the furtherance of
_examples: This money will help the development of literacy in developing countries

synsets.definition: take or use
_examples: She helped herself to some of the office supplies

synsets.definition: improve; change for the better
_examples: New slipcovers will help the old living room furniture
